title: 112_s840
content: The Act is titled the "Stop Canadian Trash Act" and includes provisions for customs user fees for commercial trucks transporting foreign municipal solid waste. The "Stop Canadian Trash Act" amends Section 13031 of the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 to include fees for commercial trucks transporting foreign municipal solid waste. The term 'municipal solid waste' refers to waste generated outside the US, including household and commercial waste like rubbish and food. The term 'municipal solid waste' includes various types of waste such as rubbish, food, yard waste, paper, clothing, appliances, consumer product packaging, disposable diapers, office supplies, cosmetics, glass and metal food containers, household hazardous waste, and debris from construction activities. The curr_chunk discusses exceptions to the term 'municipal solid waste', specifically excluding hazardous waste and waste resulting from responses to hazardous substance releases. The curr_chunk discusses exceptions to the term 'municipal solid waste', including recyclable materials separated from waste and waste used for alternative energy purposes. Exceptions to the term 'municipal solid waste' include recyclable materials and waste used for alternative energy production, as well as medical waste segregated from solid waste and solid waste generated during air transportation services. SEC. 3. Information required for customs. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish regulations within 120 days of the enactment of the Act, mandating importers of foreign municipal solid waste to provide information on each truck entering the US, including cubic feet, waste type, and any other relevant details. Failure to comply or providing false information will result in penalties. The Secretary of Homeland Security can impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for each failure or falsification, in addition to other penalties under various laws.
